channel.title: Making Games!
channel.description:
Hello Guys/Girls
I myself has been thinking on making a game, Remake of minecraft but with more features with cars to get around with and adding more pickaxes and stuff, I have never coded a game before or anything before, Im new and wanted to start out yong, Were can i get started any simple games i can learn first? Any ideas? What shall i make it in?
Please give me questions!

item.title: Making Games!
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“317guy, post:2, topic:540086”]If you have no basic Programming experience id just recommend getting a book on it most modern games are made with C++ but if you are just starting out you should try something like Python Java C# I only have experience in Java & C# (Very Similar languages) in my opinion start with a c# book this was an awesome book i got 2-3years ago it teaches you from basics. To making a mini rpg like game to a shooting game http://www.amazon.com/Head-First-C-Jennifer-Greene/dp/1449343503/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1392389058&sr=8-5&keywords=c%23
it was a fun awesome starting point it is cheap to Torrent buy aswell[/quote]

It wouldn’t be ideal to jump directly into a programming language.

@OP: I would recommend downloading GameMaker and playing around with it just to get the feel of what it’s like to create a game. Creating a game takes a lot of work, especially if you want to do the models and everything.

Read full topic

I have Java and C# experience

I personally don’t like C# because microsoft made it, and also because it is not possible to run on a normal mac.
[/quote]

Stop using mac and join the superior Windows[/quote]lololo

item.title: Making Games!
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

I’d absolutely buy a book. Not an e-book. I’d study it. Try to go through it a time or two. Do all of the examples. Ask us if you’re not fully grasping a concept, etc.

I read an earlier revision of this book. It helped me out a shit load. I really love how the author explains everything.
http://www.amazon.com/Java-The-Complete-Reference-Edition/dp/0071606300

Give it a try, dedicate as much time as you can to learning. And again, don’t hesitate to ask us.

Read full topic

item.title: Making Games!
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

I’d start by learning Java (not C++) because C++ has some confusing shit that you don’t want to be worrying about as a beginner. Once you know Java learning C++ will be easy. C++ is more relevant in the games industry and you’ll find more fancy game libraries etc, but I don’t think this is a valid reason to learn it as a first language.

Also, if you’ve never programmed anything before then expect 6-12 months just to learn Java (depending on free time etc). You’re gonna have to start with all the boring shit like adding two numbers and printing them to the console, then text based games, then eventually when you learn how to make a ball bounce on the screen it’ll become more obvious how you could attempt a real game.

So yeah just learn a language first and forget about making games for a while m8.

Read full topic
